expl: that rule is no longer in operation
operation.n.01.defn: the state of being in effect or being operative

expl: a large-scale farming operation
a multinational operation
they paid taxes on every stage of the operation
they had to consolidate their operations
operation.n.02.defn: a business especially one run on a large scale

expl: they organized a rescue operation
the biggest police operation in French history
running a restaurant is quite an operation
consolidate the companies various operations
operation.n.03.defn: a planned activity involving many people performing various actions

expl: it can perform millions of operations per second
operation.n.04.defn: (computer science) data processing in which the result is completely specified by a rule (especially the processing that results from a single instruction)

expl: it was a joint operation of the navy and air force
operation.n.05.defn: activity by a military or naval force (as a maneuver or campaign)

expl: they will schedule the operation as soon as an operating room is available
he died while undergoing surgery
operation.n.06.defn: a medical procedure involving an incision with instruments; performed to repair damage or arrest disease in a living body

expl: the operations in building a house
certain machine tool operations
operation.n.07.defn: a process or series of acts especially of a practical or mechanical nature involved in a particular form of work

expl: the power of its engine determines its operation
the plane's operation in high winds
they compared the cooking performance of each oven
the jet's performance conformed to high standards
operation.n.08.defn: process or manner of functioning or operating

expl: the process of thinking
the cognitive operation of remembering
process.n.02.defn: (psychology) the performance of some composite cognitive activity; an operation that affects mental contents

expl: the problems at the end of the chapter demonstrated the mathematical processes involved in the derivation
they were learning the basic operations of arithmetic
her smooth operation of the vehicle gave us a surprisingly comfortable ride
operation.n.11.defn: the activity of operating something (a machine or business etc.)

expl: the monarch's last days
in his final years
days.n.01.defn: the time during which someone's life continues

expl: two days later they left
they put on two performances every day
there are 30,000 passengers per day
day.n.01.defn: time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis

expl: it should arrive any day now
after that day she never trusted him again
those were the days
these days it is not unusual
day.n.02.defn: some point or period in time

expl: Mother's Day
day.n.03.defn: a day assigned to a particular purpose or observance

expl: the dawn turned night into day
it is easier to make the repairs in the daytime
day.n.04.defn: the time after sunrise and before sunset while it is light outside

expl: my day began early this morning
it was a busy day on the stock exchange
she called it a day and went to bed
day.n.05.defn: the recurring hours when you are not sleeping (especially those when you are working)

expl: in the day of the dinosaurs
in the days of the Roman Empire
in the days of sailing ships
he was a successful pianist in his day
day.n.06.defn: an era of existence or influence

expl: how long is a day on Jupiter?
day.n.07.defn: the period of time taken by a particular planet (e.g. Mars) to make a complete rotation on its axis

sidereal_day.n.01.defn: the time for one complete rotation of the earth relative to a particular star, about 4 minutes shorter than a mean solar day

expl: he deserves his day in court
every dog has his day

day.n.10.defn: United States writer best known for his autobiographical works (1874-1935)
